text.title: Run the Motion Offense in Lacrosse
text.head: Run the Motion Offense in Lacrosse
text.p: The Motion Offense is a critical part of both the men and women's lacrosse game. Implementing the Motion Offense sets up a solid foundation for your team's offense. The Motion Offense organizes the offense and creates movement of the ball until players create an opportunity to score. The key point of the Motion Offense is to never stop moving. The constant motion of the offense confuses the opposing defense and creates situations that are difficult to defend. When the offense is constantly moving, the defense does not have time to rest.
text.head: Steps

list.item: Label disc cones with the numbers 1-7.

Set up your offense. Each position in the Motion Offense is assigned a number. Facing the middle of the field: The left of the goal is #1, the right of the goal is #2, then numbers increase from 3 to 7 counter-clockwise balancing around the 12-meter arch.
Place a cone to mark the 7 starting spots of the Motion Offense.

Inform players of the following options that the ball carrier has in the motion offense:
Going to goal
Passing to an adjacent
Switching Positions

Start with the play setup. During a transition from midfield to offense, the ball carrier should look to go to goal as her first option. If the opposing defense is not set up yet, she could have an easy opportunity to shoot or draw a shooting space foul.
If the ball carrier does not have a clear path to goal, she stall the play by getting into one of the seven spots and wait for her teammates to set up Motion.

Explain to the ball carrier that the next option should be a look to pass. The ball carrier has 2 options when passing. Those two options include passing to the player to her left or passing to the player to her right. Passing to any player other than an adjacent is a risky pass and could be intercepted or deflected by the opposing defender. Passes should be quick, clean and direct. Lobbed passes could also be intercepted by a defender.
If you are a player who does not have the ball and is not directly adjacent to the ball carrier, you should be paying attention to the location of the ball. Keep the offense balanced around the 12 meter arch to create space for passing, movement and cuts.

After the ball carrier has passed it to an adjacent, have the previous ball carrier make a cut towards goal. They now become "the cutter". The cutter should be running close to full speed into the 8-meter arch in front of the goal, looking for a pass from the now-ball carrier.
If the ball carrier does not have a clean pass to the cutter, the cutter will continue running to the outside of the 8 meter arch. They will find a new spot in the Motion while the other players balance out the rest of the set-up.

Have the ball carriers continue to pass to their left or right adjacent, then cutting towards the goal. The ball should be moving fast, only staying with one player for 3-5 seconds before being passed to the next adjacent.

If a player is having a hard time getting the ball to her adjacent, she can also switch her location in the motion offense. Communication is key within the offense, so let your teammates know by yelling "switch". Your teammates will know that you are moving and will be looking out for opportunities to receive a pass.
Off-ball players can switch places with other off-ball players as well. Any movement that the offense does requires the defense to focus attention on the motion offense.
Be the first player to all ground balls. If you or a teammate drops the ball while in motion, make sure you hustle the hardest to win back the ground ball.
Be patient. Working the Motion Offense can take time. Do not rush and force passes or shots, as bad shots and bad passes are easily recovered by the opposing team.

text.head: Tips

list.item: Have your midfielders set up at the top of the arch. These players will have to run a shorter distance when they need to get back and help on defense.
Before moving to Step #3, have players pass around while calling out the numbers of the positions in the motion offense. If the ball is in spot #4, all players should be shouting "4!"

text.head: Warnings

list.item: Make sure each player is wearing protective goggles and a full mouth-guard. Goalies should also be equipped with proper padding prior to starting the instruction of the Motion Offense.
